the reactor and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC, FuLi 9790II), and the corresponding data were recorded for the initial reaction.Subsequently, the sealed quartz vessel was placed under the simulated sunlight irradiation (200 mWAcm A2 ) from Xe lamp (PLS-SXE300, Beijing Perfectlight) to trigger CO 2 reduction reaction.During the photocatalytic process, the gaseous products were determined by the GC analysis.The solution after reaction was checked by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy on a

photoelectron spectra (XPS) were acquired on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer, and the binding energies were calibrated with C 1s peak at 284.8 eV as a reference.UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were recorded on a spectrophotometer of Shimadzu UV-2600 with BaSO 4 as the reference.Photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the photocatalysts were measured on HORIBA Fluoromax-4 spectrophotometer at the excitation wavelength of 350 nm.The PL spectra of coumarin and umbelliferone

was measured under a chopped light irradiation (light onoff cycles: 30 s) from Xe lamp, with a bias potential of 0.11 V.The Mott-Schottky plots were recorded in dark at the frequencies of 500, 1000, and 1500 Hz, respectively, with the potential range from A2.0 to 2.0 V.The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were measured in the frequency range of 0.01-10 5 Hz with an amplitude of 5 mV and a bias potential of 0 V vs. AgAgCl electrode.For comparison, the transient photocurrent tests were carried out in

of coumarin and umbelliferone were measured at the excitation wavelength of 332 nm.The radicals generated during photocatalytic CO 2 reduction were identified by in situ electron spin resonance (ESR) detection on a Bruker JEOL JES-FA200 spectrometer, with 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) as a radicaltrapping reagent.
